List of Reported UFO Sightings 🔗

This Wikipedia article provides a compilation of notable reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), including claims of close encounters and alien abduction. It clarifies that UFOs encompass any aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified, noting that most are eventually explained as known objects or atmospheric phenomena. The article also mentions the use of the term “Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena” (UAP) to avoid associations with UFO conspiracy theories.

Antiquity 🔗

This section details alleged UFO sightings from ancient times, drawing from historical texts and records.

  • c. 1450 BC: The Tulli Papyrus describes a “star” that came down and set fire to enemies of Thutmose III during a battle in Ancient Egypt.
  • 218 BC: Mentions “ships in the sky” reported over Italia in the Roman Republic.
  • 76 BC: Describes a “spark from a star” that grew to the size of the Moon over Asia in the Roman Republic.
  • 73 BC: Plutarch’s account of a “flame-like body” resembling a wine-jar falling between Roman and Pontic armies in Phrygia.
  • AD 65: Flavius Josephus’s report of chariots “hurtling through the clouds” over Judaea before the First Jewish-Roman War.
  • AD 196: Cassius Dio’s description of a “fine rain resembling silver” falling on the Forum of Augustus in Rome.

8th century 🔗

This section includes a single entry:

  • AD c. 740: The “Air ship of Clonmacnoise” describes “ships with their crews were seen in the air” over Ireland.

16th–17th centuries 🔗

This section covers reports from the Renaissance and early modern periods.

  • 1561: The 1561 celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg describes an aerial battle with spheres, cylinders, and other objects.
  • 1566: The 1566 celestial phenomenon over Basel depicts spherical objects appearing out of the sun.
  • 1609: Mentions UFO turmoil during the Gwanghaegun period in Joseon (Korea), with multiple witnesses describing a divided “halo” or “washbowl” in the sky.

19th century 🔗

This section lists sightings from the 1800s.

  • 1883: The Bonilla observation involves astronomer José Bonilla photographing hundreds of dark objects crossing the sun in Mexico.
  • 1896-1897: The Mystery airships wave across the United States, with reports of strange airships and lights.
  • 1897: The Aurora, Texas, UFO incident, where a local correspondent reported the crash of an airship piloted by an alien.

20th century 🔗

This section is divided into two sub-sections: 1900-1949 and 1950-1974.

1900–1949 🔗

  • 1904: USS Supply sighting of three red objects in geometrical formation flight pattern in the North Pacific.
  • 1907: Mihal Grameno UFO sighting in Albania, where a shiny object was seen hovering in the air.
  • 1909: New Zealand airship sightings, with reports of moving lights and whirring sounds.
  • 1917: The Miracle of the Sun in Fátima, Portugal, interpreted by some as a mass UFO sighting.
  • 1926: Nicholas Roerich UFO sighting in Tibet, describing an oval object in the sky.
  • 1933: Frank Smythe UFO sighting on Mount Everest, witnessing two spots hovering in the sky.
  • 1940s: Foo fighters reported by Allied fighter pilots during World War II.
  • 1941: Cape Girardeau UFO legend, involving a crashed flying saucer and dying crew.
  • 1942: The Battle of Los Angeles, where U.S. radar stations picked up an unidentified aerial object.
  • 1942: Army Air Corps Flying School near Columbus, Missouri, control tower operator observes two reddish colored round objects descend-hover-accelerate away.
  • 1944: 468th Bomb Group returning from a bombing mission at an altitude of 14000 feet, speed “about 210 mph”: 500 yards (about 457 meters) from the starboard an object appeared which the pilot estimated at the distance viewed was “probably 5-6 feet in diameter” (1.5-1.8 meters) - “intense red or orange” color - throbbed or vibrated constantly.

item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) 🔗

An unidentified flying object (UFO), also known as unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) or unidentified anomalous phenomena, is defined as an object or phenomenon observed in the sky that cannot be readily identified or explained. While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back to at least the 3rd century BC, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II and during the Space Age. Most UFOs are later identified as known objects or atmospheric phenomena, but a small percentage remain unexplained.

Terminology 🔗

During the late 1940s and 1950s, UFOs were commonly referred to as “flying saucers” or “flying discs,” stemming from the Kenneth Arnold incident. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt of the USAF coined the acronym “UFO” to encompass the diverse range of reported shapes and performances. “Unidentified aerial phenomena” (UAP) emerged in the late 1960s and has seen increased usage in the 21st century, partly to avoid the negative connotations associated with “UFO.” In popular culture, “UFO” often implies an alien spacecraft, while the term “extra-terrestrial vehicle” (ETV) is sometimes used to distinguish this explanation from earthbound ones.

Identification 🔗

Studies indicate that most UFOs, upon thorough investigation, are identifiable as ordinary objects or phenomena. Common sources of UFO reports include aircraft (military, civilian, experimental, drones), astronomical objects (bright stars, planets, meteors), balloons (weather, research, toy), hoaxes, light phenomena (mirages, flares, searchlights), other atmospheric objects (birds, unusual clouds, plasma), and psychological effects (pareidolia, hallucinations). Allan Hendry’s 1979 study found that fewer than 1% of investigated cases were hoaxes, with most sightings being misidentifications due to inexperience or misperception. Astronomer Andrew Fraknoi encourages critical thinking when evaluating UFO claims, suggesting that increased investigation often reveals less mystery than initially perceived.

History 🔗

Early history before the 20th century 🔗

Throughout history, people have observed unusual sights in the sky, including comets, meteors, planets, and optical phenomena. Halley’s Comet, for example, was recorded by Chinese astronomers as early as 240 BC. Such events were often interpreted as supernatural portents or religious omens. While some UFO enthusiasts draw parallels between religious symbols in medieval paintings and UFO reports, art historians offer conventional religious interpretations.

Examples of pre-contemporary reports include:

  • Julius Obsequens’ Liber de prodigiis, which describes objects moving through the sky in ancient Rome.
  • Shen Kuo’s Dream Pool Essays (1088), which recounts eyewitness testimony of a flying object with opening doors and blinding light in 11th-century China.
  • Woodcuts from 1561 and 1566 depicting celestial phenomena over Nuremberg and Basel, respectively, which some connect to ancient astronaut claims.
  • An 1878 Denison Daily News article reporting John Martin’s sighting of a large, dark, circular object, one of the first uses of the word “saucer” in association with a UFO.
  • Numerous reports of “mystery airships” in United States newspapers from 1896 to 1897.

20th century and after 🔗

During World War II, Allied and Axis pilots reported round, glowing fireballs known as “foo fighters.” Explanations for these sightings ranged from St. Elmo’s fire to German secret weapons. In 1946, over 2,000 reports of unidentified aerial objects, dubbed “ghost rockets,” were collected, primarily by the Swedish military.

The modern UFO phenomenon gained momentum with Kenneth Arnold’s widely reported sighting in 1947, where he described seeing “flying saucers” near Mount Rainier. This event sparked a media frenzy and numerous subsequent sightings. Weeks later, the Roswell incident occurred, involving the recovery of a downed observation balloon.

In the early 1950s, “saucer clubs” emerged, and influential books by Donald Keyhoe, Frank Scully, and Gerald Heard promoted the extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis. Media speculation intensified, particularly during the 1952 UFO scare in Washington, D.C.

From 1947, the U.S. Air Force initiated investigations into UFO reports through Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book. Project Blue Book cataloged 12,618 sightings between 1952 and 1969. Public pressure for declassification of UFO records mounted, but the CIA resisted.

From the 1960s to 1990s, UFOs became integrated into American popular culture, with the Barney and Betty Hill alien abduction account gaining notoriety. In 1966, a Gallup poll revealed that 5% of Americans claimed to have seen a “flying saucer.” Despite efforts to debunk UFO claims, public fascination persisted, fueled by sci-fi films and TV shows.

In December 2017, media attention surged following The New York Times’ report on the secret Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program. Leaked Pentagon UFO videos further heightened interest. In July 2021, Harvard astronomer Avi Loeb announced the Galileo Project to seek evidence of extraterrestrial artifacts. Government-sponsored programs, such as NASA’s UAP independent study team and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, were established to investigate UFO claims more thoroughly.

A Harris Poll in 2009 indicated that 32% of Americans believed in UFOs. A 2021 Pew research poll found that 51% in the United States thought that UFOs reported by people in the military were likely to be evidence of intelligent life from beyond the Earth.

Notable cases and incidents 🔗

Notable cases and incidents include:

  • Britain: The Rendlesham Forest incident (1980).
  • France: The Valensole UFO incident (1965) and the Trans-en-Provence Case (1981).
  • United States: The Kecksburg UFO incident (1965), the Travis Walton abduction claim (1975), and the Phoenix Lights (1997).

Famous hoaxes include the Maury Island incident and the George Adamski claims.

Investigations of reports 🔗

UFO reports have been investigated by governments and academics in various countries. No official government investigation has definitively confirmed that UFOs are real, physical objects of extraterrestrial origin or a threat to national defense.

Well-known government studies include:

  • The Swedish military’s ghost rockets investigation (1946–1947).
  • The USAF’s Project Blue Book (1947–1969).
  • The U.S. Army/Air Force Project Twinkle investigation into green fireballs (1948–1951).
  • The Brazilian Air Force’s Operação Prato (Operation Saucer) (1977).
  • France’s GEPAN/SEPRA/GEIPAN investigation (1977–present).
  • Uruguay’s government investigation (1989–present).

Americas 🔗

Brazil (1952–2016) 🔗

The National Archives of Brazil holds documentation from the Brazilian Air Force regarding UFO investigations between 1952 and 2016.

Chile (c. 1968) 🔗

The SEFAA (previously CEFAA), a department of the DGAC, receives reports of UFO sightings from the public, civil aviators, and the Chilean Air Force.

Canada (c. 1950) 🔗

The Department of National Defence has investigated UFO reports across Canada, including the Falcon Lake incident and the Shag Harbour UFO incident. Early Canadian studies included Project Magnet (1950–1954) and Project Second Storey (1952–1954).

United States 🔗

U.S. investigations into UFOs include Project Sign, Project Grudge, Project Blue Book, Project Twinkle, the CIA’s DS&T study, the Robertson Panel, the Brookings Report, the Condon Committee, the RAND Corporation study, the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON), the National Investigations Committee On Aerial Phenomena (NICAP), the Center for UFO Studies (CUFOS), the Sturrock panel, the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office.

Following a surge in sightings in 1947, the USAAF and FBI began a formal investigation. A preliminary defense estimate concluded that “something is really flying around.”

The Condon Committee’s negative conclusion in 1968 led to the closure of Project Blue Book in 1970. However, a 1969 USAF document, the Bolender memo, revealed that non-public U.S. government UFO investigations continued after 1970.

item.title: Unidentified flying object
item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) 🔗

An unidentified flying object (UFO), also known as unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP), is defined as an object or phenomenon observed in the sky that cannot be readily identified or explained. While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back centuries, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II, particularly during the Space Age. Investigations into UFO reports have been conducted by governments, organizations, and individuals, but no definitive confirmation of claims suggesting extraterrestrial origins or other unconventional explanations has emerged. Skeptics often attribute UFO sightings to misidentified natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, or hoaxes.

Terminology 🔗

The terms “flying saucers” or “flying discs” were initially used to describe UFOs, stemming from the Kenneth Arnold incident. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt of the USAF coined the acronym “UFO” to encompass a broader range of reported shapes and performances. “Unidentified aerial phenomena” (UAP) emerged later, gaining traction in the 21st century due to negative connotations associated with “UFO.” The term “extra-terrestrial vehicle” (ETV) is sometimes used to distinguish between extraterrestrial and earthbound explanations for UFOs.

Identification 🔗

Most UFOs, upon investigation, are identified as ordinary objects or phenomena. Common sources of UFO reports include aircraft (military, civilian, experimental, drones), astronomical objects (bright stars, planets, meteors), balloons (weather, research, toy), hoaxes, light phenomena (mirages, flares, searchlights), other atmospheric objects (birds, unusual clouds, plasma), and psychological effects (pareidolia, hallucinations). Studies, such as one by CUFOS researcher Allan Hendry, have found that most sightings are honest misidentifications of prosaic phenomena due to inexperience or misperception.

History 🔗

Early history before the 20th century 🔗

Throughout history, people have observed unusual sights in the sky, including comets, meteors, planets, and optical phenomena. These events were often interpreted as supernatural portents or religious omens. While some UFO enthusiasts draw parallels between religious symbols in medieval paintings and UFO reports, art historians offer conventional religious interpretations.

Examples of pre-contemporary reports include:

  • Julius Obsequens’ Liber de prodigiis, which describes things moving through the sky.
  • Shen Kuo’s Dream Pool Essays, which recounts eyewitness testimony of a flying object with opening doors and blinding light in 11th-century China.
  • Woodcuts and leaflets from the 15th and 16th centuries depicting “miracles” and “sky spectacles.”
  • John Martin’s 1878 report of a large, dark, circular object resembling a balloon flying at high speed.

20th century and after 🔗

During World War II, Allied and Axis pilots reported seeing round, glowing fireballs known as “foo fighters.” Explanations for these sightings ranged from St. Elmo’s fire to German secret weapons. In 1946, over 2,000 reports of unidentified aerial objects over Scandinavia, referred to as “ghost rockets,” were collected.

The modern UFO phenomenon gained momentum with the widely reported sighting by Kenneth Arnold in 1947, who described seeing “flying saucers.” This sparked a media frenzy and numerous reports of similar sightings, including the Roswell incident. UFO enthusiasts formed “saucer clubs,” and books promoting the extraterrestrial hypothesis gained popularity.

In the U.S., media accounts and speculation led to the 1952 UFO scare in Washington, D.C. From 1947 to 1969, the U.S. Air Force investigated UFO reports through Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book. The CIA also conducted a study in 1952, concluding that UFOs were real physical objects of potential threat. Public pressure for declassification of UFO records mounted, but the CIA resisted.

Official U.S. Air Force interest waned after the Condon Report in 1969, which concluded that further study of UFOs was not justified. However, some government documents suggest that non-public UFO investigations continued.

From the 1960s to 1990s, UFOs became part of popular culture’s fascination with the supernatural and paranormal. The Barney and Betty Hill alien abduction account gained notoriety, and UFO stories were featured in TV shows and films.

In December 2017, media attention resurfaced with the revelation of the secret Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program. Leaked Pentagon UFO videos led to increased mainstream interest in UFO stories. In July 2021, Harvard astronomer Avi Loeb announced the Galileo Project to seek evidence of extraterrestrial artifacts. Government-sponsored programs, such as NASA’s UAP independent study team and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, were established to investigate UFO claims. Congressional hearings were held to discuss military reports of UAPs.

Public belief in UFOs varies, with polls showing that a significant percentage of Americans believe UFOs are evidence of alien life.

Notable cases and incidents 🔗

Britain 🔗

  • The Rendlesham Forest incident (1980) involved reported sightings of unexplained lights near Rendlesham Forest in Suffolk, England.

France 🔗

  • The Valensole UFO incident (1965).
  • The Trans-en-Provence Case (1981).

United States 🔗

  • The Kecksburg UFO incident (1965) in Pennsylvania.
  • Travis Walton’s alleged alien abduction (1975).
  • The “Phoenix Lights” (1997) in Arizona.

Famous hoaxes 🔗

  • The Maury Island incident.
  • George Adamski’s claims of meetings with telepathic aliens.
  • Ed Walters’ Gulf Breeze UFO incident (1987) in Florida.

Investigations of reports 🔗

UFO reports have been investigated by governments and academics in various countries. No official government investigation has publicly concluded that UFOs are indisputably real, physical objects of extraterrestrial origin, or a threat to national defense.

Notable government studies include the Swedish military’s ghost rockets investigation, Project Blue Book, Project Twinkle, and Brazil’s Operação Prato. France has had an ongoing investigation (GEPAN/SEPRA/GEIPAN) since 1977, and Uruguay has had a similar investigation since 1989.

Americas 🔗

Brazil (1952–2016) 🔗

The National Archives of Brazil has been receiving documentation from the Brazilian Air Force regarding UFO investigations between 1952 and 2016.

Chile (c. 1968) 🔗

The SEFAA (previously CEFAA) has been receiving case reports of UFO sightings in Chile since 1968.

Canada (c. 1950) 🔗

The Department of National Defence has investigated UFO reports across Canada, including the Falcon Lake incident and the Shag Harbour UFO incident. Early Canadian studies included Project Magnet and Project Second Storey.

United States 🔗

U.S. investigations into UFOs include Project Sign, Project Grudge, Project Blue Book, Project Twinkle, the CIA’s Directorate of Science & Technology study, the Robertson Panel, the Brookings Report, the Condon Committee, the RAND Corporation study, the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON), the National Investigations Committee On Aerial Phenomena (NICAP), the Center for UFO Studies (CUFOS), the Sturrock panel, the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office.

Following a surge in sightings in 1947, the USAAF and FBI began a formal investigation. A preliminary defense estimate concluded that “something is really flying around.”

Air Force Regulation 200-2 (1953–1954) defined an Unidentified Flying Object (“UFOB”) and outlined investigation procedures.

The Condon Committee’s negative conclusion in 1968 led to the closure of Project Blue Book in 1970. However, some documents suggest that non-public U.S. government UFO investigations continued.

In November 2011, the White House released an official response stating that the U.S. government has no evidence of extraterrestrial life or government interactions with extraterrestrial beings.

In 2021, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence released a report on UAPs, finding that the UAPTF was unable to identify 143 objects spotted between 2004 and 2021.

Uruguay (c. 1989) 🔗

The Uruguayan Air Force has conducted UFO investigations since 1989, analyzing approximately 2,100 cases.

Europe 🔗

France (1977–2008) 🔗

In March 2007, the French space agency CNES published an archive of UFO sightings online. French studies include GEPAN/SEPRA/GEIPAN, which has studied 6,000 cases, with about 22% remaining unexplained. In 2008, the Sigma Commission was created to investigate UFO phenomena worldwide.

Italy (1933–2005) 🔗

Alleged UFO sightings have gradually increased since the war, peaking in 1978 and 2005.

This section mentions a fiery pillar sighting near Athens during a stormy, moonless night in 404 BC.

item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the nation of Argentina 🔗

This article presents a compilation of reported UFO sightings in Argentina, spanning from 1962 to 2023.

May 1962 🔗

This section details several UFO sightings that occurred in May 1962, primarily around Bahía Blanca. Key events include:

  • Sightings at the Espora Air Base on May 11 and 18.
  • An encounter on Route 35 where three truck drivers witnessed an illuminated object rising from a field and dividing into two parts.
  • A photograph taken by Miguel Tohmé in Bahía Blanca on May 21, depicting a UFO “the size of a soccer ball.”
  • Sightings at the Port Belgrano Naval Base between May 21 and 23.

16 July 1965 🔗

This section describes a sighting in Buenos Aires on July 16, 1965, where two bright disks were observed remaining stationary before flying away at high speed. The Seventh Air Brigade dispatched three Gloster Meteor aircraft from Morón Air Base to investigate, but the search yielded no results.

1 December 1965 🔗

This section refers to the Adhara Observatory UFO Lunar Transit. On December 1, 1965, at 8:30 pm, the Adhara Observatory in San Miguel, Buenos Aires province, received calls about strange objects visible on the moon. Photographs taken by the observatory staff revealed disk-shaped objects flying in front of the moon. Some experts suggest these objects may have been caused by film processing errors.

27 October 1973 🔗

This section recounts the experience of truck driver Dionisio Llanca, who was admitted to the Municipal Hospital of Bahía Blanca on October 30. Llanca claimed that on October 27, he encountered an intense light while changing a tire on his way to Río Gallegos, which paralyzed him. He reported seeing an object in the sky and beings who subjected him to medical testing. He awoke hours later approximately 9 kilometers away. UFO researcher Fabio Zerpa investigated the case and published it in his book El Reino Subterráneo.

9 January 1986 🔗

This section discusses an alleged UFO landing on Mount Pajarillo, near Capilla del Monte. An 11-year-old local child, Gabriel Gomez, witnessed the event. The following day, a circular footprint, known as “Huella del Pajarillo,” appeared near Cerro Uritorco, believed to be the result of a UFO landing that burned the area in a circular shape.

25 December 1988 🔗

This section describes a sighting over Villa Urquiza, Buenos Aires, where a silver UFO flew over the high-density area. This event is considered one of Argentina’s most spectacular UFO incidents, with over 7,500 witnesses. The local airport reported an object flying west towards General Paz Avenue, detected on radar on that sunny afternoon.

5 September 2023 🔗

This section details an incident at the Espora Air Base near Bahía Blanca. On that night, four black, triangular UFOs allegedly flew over the base and were engaged with gunfire by military personnel. One object reportedly fired a laser, injuring two or three soldiers. The Base denied the incident, claiming that videos and audios circulating were edited fake news.

This section contains footnotes referencing the sources used for each of the sightings described in the article.

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Flying Saucer 🔗

A flying saucer, or flying disc, is a purported type of disc-shaped unidentified flying object (UFO). The term originated in 1947 when US news media reported pilot Kenneth Arnold’s claim of seeing objects flying near his airplane over Washington State. The news reports included implausible speed estimates and preceded a wave of sightings across the US, including the Roswell incident and the Flight 105 UFO sighting. A National Guard pilot died in 1948 while pursuing a flying saucer. Civilian research groups and conspiracy theories developed around the topic, and the concept spread to other countries. Early reports speculated about secret military technology, but flying saucers became associated with aliens by 1950. The terms unidentified flying object (UFO) and unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) have gradually replaced the term over time.

An aerial photo taken over Lake Cote, Costa Rica, by Sergio Loaiza in 1971 is included.

In science fiction, UFO sightings, UFO conspiracy theories, and popular culture, saucers are typically piloted by nonhuman beings. Most reported sightings describe saucers in the distance and do not mention a crew. Descriptions of the craft vary considerably. Early reports emphasized speed, but the descriptions shifted over the decades to the objects mostly hovering. They are generally said to be round, sometimes with a protrusion on top, but details of the shape vary between reports. Witnesses describe flying saucers as silent or deafening, with lights of every color, and flying alone or in formation. Size estimates range from small enough to fit in a living room to over 2,000 feet (610 m) in diameter. Sightings are most frequent at night. Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel concluded that the reports were too varied to all be describing the same type of objects. Experts have identified most reported saucers as known phenomena, including astronomical objects such as Venus, airborne objects such as balloons, and optical phenomena such as sun dogs.

1950s pop culture embraced flying saucers. The discs appeared in film, television, literature, music, toys, and advertising. Their reports influenced religious movements and were the subject of military investigations. The shape became visual shorthand for alien invaders. During the 1960s, saucers waned in popularity as UFOs were reported and depicted in other shapes. Discs ceased to be viewed as the standard shape for alien spacecraft but are still often depicted, sometimes for their retro value to evoke the early Cold War era.

History 🔗

Reports of fantastical aircraft predate the first flying saucers. In antiquity, mysterious lights in the sky were interpreted as spiritual phenomena. In the 1800s, many newspapers reported massive airships with glowing lights and humming engines. These are often seen as precursors to flying saucer and UFO sightings. On January 25, 1878, the Denison Daily News printed an article in which John Martin, a local farmer, reported an object resembling a balloon flying “at wonderful speed”. The newspaper said it appeared to be about the size of a saucer from his perspective, one of the first uses of the word “saucer” in association with a UFO. An outbreak of a number of sightings of mystery airships occurred in America in 1896 and 1897. During World War II, Allied pilots reported balls of light following their planes. They named the lights foo fighters and believed they were advanced Axis aircraft.

Many aspects of the typical flying saucer first appeared in science fiction. French sociologist Bertrand Méheust noted Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante (The Lightning Wheel). In the novel, a flying disc-shaped machine abducts the protagonists via a beam of light. Science fiction magazine Amazing Stories began publishing “The Shaver Mystery” in 1945. Written by Richard Sharpe Shaver and edited by Raymond A. Palmer, they were science fiction tales about technologically advanced “detrimental robots” that abducted humans, but the stories were presented as a true account of Shaver’s life. Until the magazine ceased printing The Shaver Mystery, Amazing Stories’ letter column was regularly full of readers sharing their own purportedly true sightings of the robots.

Before the flying saucer was coined as a term, fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicted flying discs. Skeptical physicist Milton Rothman noted the appearance of so-called flying saucers in the fantasy artwork of 1930s pulp science fiction magazines, by artists such as Frank R. Paul. One of Paul’s earliest depictions of a flying saucer appeared on the cover of the November 1929 issue of Hugo Gernsback’s pulp science fiction magazine Science Wonder Stories. Science fiction illustrator Frank Wu wrote that the idea of space vehicles shaped like flying saucers was imprinted in the national psyche for many years prior to 1947, when the Roswell incident took place.

Origins 🔗

The modern flying saucer concept, including the association with aliens, can be traced to the 1947 Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting. On June 24, 1947, businessman and amateur pilot Kenneth Arnold landed at the Yakima, Washington airstrip. He told staff and friends that he’d seen nine unusual airborne objects. Arnold estimated their speed at 1,700 miles per hour, beyond the capabilities of known aircraft. Newspapers soon contacted Arnold for interviews. The East Oregonian reported his supposed aircraft as “saucer-like”. In a June 26 radio interview, Arnold described them as “something like a pie plate that was cut in half with a sort of a convex triangle in the rear”. Headline writers coined the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disk” (or “disc”) for the story. Arnold later told CBS News that the early coverage “did not quote me properly […] when I described how they flew, I said that they flew like they take a saucer and throw it across the water. Most of the newspapers misunderstood and misquoted that, too. They said that I said that they were saucer-like; I said that they flew in a saucer-like fashion.” The circular shape of typical flying saucers may be due to reporters mistaking Arnold’s “saucer-like” description of motion.

Arnold’s story preceded a wave of hundreds of flying saucer reports. Lieutenant Governor of Idaho Donald S. Whitehead claimed he saw a fast-moving object resembling a meteor around the time of Arnold’s sighting. In early July, head of Air Materiel Command Nathan F. Twining told reporters that “anyone seeing the objects” should contact Wright Field. The next widely publicized report was the sighting by a United Airlines crew on July 4 of nine more disc-like objects pacing their plane over Idaho.

The public was divided on the potential origin of the saucers. Arnold told military intelligence officers he suspected the discs were experimental aircraft, and early newspapers reported Arnold saying, “I don’t know what they were—unless they were guided missiles.” News media speculated on a Soviet origin, and many war veterans connected them to the foo fighters seen during World War II. A Gallup Poll found that 90% of Americans were aware of the saucer stories, and 16 percent believed they were secret military weapons, most likely American. The most common explanation given was some type of illusion or mirage. Less than one percent believed they were alien craft. One report from Seattle, Washington, described a hammer and sickle painted onto a flying disc. The stories spread to other countries, where they were influenced by local political and social concerns. In Europe, which was still recovering from the Second World War, saucers were often reported with rocket-like features. German newspapers reported flying saucers that exploded or had tails of fire. The names for the discs were largely derived from the English “flying saucer” including the French soucoupe volante, Spanish platillo volante, Portuguese disco voador, Swedish flygande tefat, German fliegende Untertasse, and Italian disco volante.

The 1947 sightings peaked in the days after the Fourth of July and declined rapidly through mid-July. Multiple organizations offered $1,000 rewards for hard proof. In the widely reported July 7, 1947, Twin Falls saucer hoax, four teenagers in Idaho fabricated a crashed disc from jukebox parts. On July 8, the Army Air Force base at Roswell, New Mexico, issued a press release saying that they had recovered a “flying disc” from a nearby ranch; the so-called Roswell UFO incident made front-page news. International media covered the military’s announcement of a crashed disc, but within 24 hours were reporting the military’s retraction and explanation that the material was balloon debris. By July 11, the most widely reported story was a North Hollywood resident’s claim that a 30-inch galvanized iron disc containing glass radio tubes had crashed in his garden. Newspapers quoted Fire Battalion Chief Wallace Newcombe’s assessment, “It doesn’t look to me like it could fly.”

The Air Force collected over a hundred reports at Wright Field, now Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio. Air Force General Nathan Twining established Project SAUCER, later renamed Project Sign, the first in a series of UFO investigations by the US Government. Other national governments followed suit. Canada began Project Magnet and the United Kingdom launched the Flying Saucer Working Party in 1950, which attributed saucer reports to meteorological phenomena, astronomical phenomena, misidentification, optical illusions, misconceptions, or hoaxes

item.title: UFO flap
item.description:
UFO Flap 🔗

A UFO flap refers to a sudden increase in reports of unidentified flying objects (UFOs). The term “flap,” originally a military term for a period of panic or chaos, is used by ufologists to describe surges of sightings in a specific geographical area. Larger surges spanning multiple countries are sometimes called “waves.” The frequency of UFO sightings, public interest, and news coverage varies significantly. The terms UFO, flap, and wave allow for the discussion of various unrelated phenomena in the night sky as if they are part of the same aerial event.

Wired journalist Sarah Scoles traced the origin of the term “UFO flap” to the 1947 flying saucer craze, which began with Kenneth Arnold’s sighting. Edward Ruppelt, an Air Force officer involved in governmental UFO investigations, defined “flap” in Air Force terminology as a state of confusion that hasn’t reached panic. Scoles suggests that even without Arnold’s sighting, a similar event would have occurred due to the cultural climate of the time, characterized by fear of outsiders, fear of invasions, and awe of technology. UFO flaps can be intensified by hoaxers exploiting the increased interest.

Notable Flaps 🔗

This section lists specific instances of UFO flaps throughout history.

  • Mystery airship wave of 1896–1897: A series of sightings of mysterious airships across the United States.
  • Foo fighters of World War II: Reports of unusual aerial phenomena by military pilots during World War II.
  • Ghost rockets of 1946: Sightings of unidentified rocket-like objects over Sweden and Finland.
  • 1947 flying disc craze: A surge of UFO sightings in the United States, triggered by Kenneth Arnold’s sighting. Key events include the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting, Flight 105 UFO sighting, the Roswell incident, the Rhodes photographs, the Twin Falls saucer hoax, and the Maury Island hoax.
  • 1952 UFO Flap: A significant increase in UFO sightings, including the Wonsan-Sunchon UFO incident, the publication of “Have We Visitors From Space?”, the Passaic UFO photographs, the 1952 Washington, D.C., UFO incident, and the release of “The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects.”
  • Great 1954 Greek UFO flap: A period of heightened UFO activity in Greece.
  • Michigan “swamp gas” UFO reports: A series of UFO sightings in Michigan, later attributed to swamp gas.
  • 1967 UFO flap in Britain: A surge of UFO sightings in the United Kingdom.
  • 1977 Colares flap: A series of UFO sightings and alleged encounters in Brazil.
  • 1984 Hudson Valley UFO sightings: A wave of UFO sightings in the Hudson Valley region of the United States.
  • Gulf Breeze UFO incident of 1987–88: A controversial series of UFO sightings and photographs in Gulf Breeze, Florida.
  • Belgian UFO wave of 1989–90: A large number of UFO sightings, including triangular-shaped objects, over Belgium.
  • 1994 Michigan UFO event: A widely reported UFO sighting in Michigan.
  • Phoenix Lights of 1997: A mass sighting of unidentified lights over Phoenix, Arizona.
  • 2024 Northeastern United States drone sightings: Recent reports of drone sightings in the Northeastern United States.

See Also 🔗

This section lists related topics.

  • Extraterrestrial hypothesis: The idea that UFO reports are best explained as interplanetary or interstellar spacecraft.
  • Psychosocial hypothesis: The idea that UFO reports are best explained by social contagion.
  • UFO conspiracy theories: Theories that governments or other organizations are concealing information about UFOs.

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis 🔗

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term 🔗

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature back to the mid-1960s. Key figures mentioned include French ufologist Jacques Vallée, who used the term in his 1966 book, and French engineer Aimé Michel. James E. McDonald and James Harder also used the term in 1968 during a symposium and congressional testimony. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in the Condon Report (1969). Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology 🔗

This section explores the historical context of the ETH, tracing its origins to earlier concepts such as Percival Lowell’s ideas about Martian canals and civilizations, the science fiction writings of H.G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century. The modern ETH took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience, popular culture, and unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups like NICAP and APRO.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits 🔗

This section presents early examples of speculation about extraterrestrial visitors, including an 1864 French newspaper story about the discovery of an alien-like creature. It discusses H.G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” and the “mystery airships” reported in the late 19th century. Mentions comic strips and radio/movie serials like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon, which popularized the idea of alien visitation. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” is also noted for causing public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America 🔗

This section focuses on the surge of UFO sightings in 1947, beginning with Kenneth Arnold’s report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier. It notes that Arnold considered the possibility of extraterrestrial origins and that the ETH was discussed in newspapers and letters to the editor. Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet is mentioned, as is R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that the saucers could be vehicles from Mars or other planets. The section also references Charles Fort’s earlier documentation of unidentified flying objects.

Evolution of Public Opinion 🔗

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions movies from the 1950s depicting flying saucers and aliens, such as “The Day the Earth Stood Still” and “The War of the Worlds.” A 1951 Popular Science poll indicated that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen man-made aircraft, while a small percentage believed they had seen alien craft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A 2002 Roper poll reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion 🔗

This section briefly mentions the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA 🔗

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP using scientific methods and an agnostic approach. Kopparapu presented a paper in August 2021 supporting the ETH.

Private or Government Studies 🔗

This section highlights private and government studies that have supported the ETH or had members who disagreed with official conclusions. Examples include a 1948 USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins, and the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for unexplained cases. It also mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. The CIA’s internal scientific review and the views of individuals within Project Blue Book, such as Major Dewey Fournet and Edward J. Ruppelt, are discussed. Statements by CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter and Greek physicist Paul Santorini are also included. The section further mentions the COMETA report (1999) and the views of Jean-Jacques Velasco, head of the French UFO investigation SEPRA, and Yves Sillard, head of GEIPAN.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH 🔗

This section presents critical responses to the ETH, noting that there is no scientific proof to back up claims of alien encounters. It states that no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery 🔗

This section discusses the U.S. military’s involvement in investigating UFOs, including the formation of Project Sign in 1947. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also mentions the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which recommended a policy of public debunkery to reduce the number of UFO reports.

Involvement of Scientists 🔗

This section highlights the scientific community’s skepticism towards the ETH. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism and quotes Carl Sagan’s statement about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation. Peter A. Sturrock’s call for examining other possible theories is also included. The section presents results from Sturrock’s polls of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics and American Astronomical Society members, showing limited support for the ETH. It summarizes J. Allen Hynek’s seven key reasons for not accepting the ETH, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology 🔗

This section notes that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, which has challenged the claimed phenomenology of UFOs and caused a crisis of confidence among some UFO researchers.

NASA 🔗

This section states NASA’s official position as of 2006, which is that the ETH lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits.

CIA 🔗

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the Robertson Panel in 1953 to debunk data collected by Project Blue Book.

Official White House Position 🔗

This section presents the White House’s official response in November 2011 to petitions asking the U.S. government to acknowledge alien visits and disclose any withholding of government interactions with extraterrestrial beings. The response states that the U.S. government has no evidence of life outside our planet or that an extraterrestrial presence has contacted or engaged any member of the human race.

Counter Critique of the Official Position: Conspiracy Theories 🔗

This section discusses the concept of a conspiracy of silence or official cover-up to suppress information about UFOs. It mentions James Harder’s argument in 1968 that significant evidence existed to prove UFOs but had been suppressed. A 1971 survey showed that more Americans believed the government was concealing information about UFOs than believed in the existence of UFOs or the ETH itself. Comments from former NASA astronauts Gordon Cooper and Brian O’Leary about NASA and the government suppressing UFO sightings are also included.

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis 🔗

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term 🔗

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature. It notes that the term gained traction in the latter half of the 1960s, with early usage attributed to French ufologist Jacques Vallée in his 1966 book. Other figures who used the term in the late 1960s include Aimé Michel, James E. McDonald, and James Harder. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in 1969 when presenting the findings of the Condon Report. Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology 🔗

This section explores the historical context leading up to the modern ETH. It traces the origins of the idea of extraterrestrial life and visitation to earlier concepts, including Percival Lowell’s theories about Martian canals and ancient Martian civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH, linking unidentified aircraft to alien life, took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits 🔗

This section presents examples of early speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a French newspaper story from 1864 about the discovery of an alien-like creature inside an egg-shaped structure. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” (1898), which popularized the idea of Martian visitation and invasion. The section notes a surge in “mystery airship” reports in the late 19th century, with some speculating about Martian origins. It also mentions the influence of comic strips, radio shows, and movies like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon in popularizing the idea of alien visitation in spaceships. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” caused some public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America 🔗

This section focuses on the events surrounding the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947 and the subsequent “flying saucer” craze. It details Arnold’s initial report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier and his consideration of the possibility of extraterrestrial origins. The section notes the widespread speculation in newspapers about the nature of the “saucers,” including theories about secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria. It mentions Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet and R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The section also cites journalist Edward R. Murrow’s observation that the ETH did not gain widespread attention until about 18 months after Arnold’s sighting.

Evolution of Public Opinion 🔗

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of the first U.S. poll of public UFO perceptions by Gallup in August 1947, which showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation for the sightings. The section also discusses the influence of movies depicting flying saucers and aliens in the early 1950s. It cites a poll published in Popular Science magazine in 1951, which reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion 🔗

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA 🔗

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP with an agnostic approach, involving experts from various fields to collect data and deduce the identity of such UAP. In August 2021, Kopparapu presented a paper supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies 🔗

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or have had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 Top Secret USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for the most perplexing unexplained cases. The section mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the CIA’s internal scientific review of UFOs in the early 1950s, noting that some CIA scientists were seriously considering the ETH. The section mentions extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book, including Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who later became a staunch supporter of the ETH. It also cites statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who urged Congressional action to reduce the dangers from secrecy about unidentified flying objects. The section mentions Greek physicist Paul Santorini’s claim that a 1947 Greek government investigation into the European Ghost rockets concluded that they were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the 1968 Condon Report, noting that many members of the study disagreed with Condon’s methods and biases. The section mentions the 1999 private French COMETA report, which concluded that the hypothesis of extraterrestrial visitors best accounted for the facts. It also discusses Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, who stated that 14% of the cases studied by SEPRA were ‘utterly inexplicable and extraterrestrial’ in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH 🔗

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It notes that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien encounters. It states that despite ardent believers, no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that various UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery 🔗

This section discusses the U.S. military’s investigation of UFOs and its efforts to debunk the ETH. It mentions the formation of Project Sign in 1947, the first official U.S. military UFO study. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also discusses the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which was organized in 1953 to review the Blue Book’s best evidence and recommend an official policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists 🔗

This section examines the scientific community’s response to the ETH. It notes that the scientific community has shown very little support for the ETH, largely accepting the explanation that UFO reports are the result of misinterpretations or hoaxes. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism about the ETH. The section cites Carl Sagan’s observation about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s statement about the narrow polarization of the UFO debate around the ETH. The section presents the results of a 1973 poll of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics members, which found that about 10% believed that UFOs were vehicles from outer space. It also presents the results of a 1977 poll of American Astronomical Society members, which asked them to assign probabilities to eight possible explanations for UFOs. The section summarizes the primary scientific arguments against ETH, as outlined by J. Allen Hynek, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon in time and space, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology 🔗

This section discusses the argument that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, calling into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA 🔗

This section presents NASA’s official standpoint on the ETH, which is that it lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits and that no claims of UFOs as being alien craft have any validity.

CIA 🔗

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

List of alleged UFO sightings in the United States 🔗

This is a compilation of reported UFO sightings within the United States, presented in a table format. Each entry includes the date of the sighting, the city and state where it occurred, a link to a main article if available, and a brief description of the event.

Table of Sightings 🔗

The table lists alleged UFO sightings chronologically, starting from September 1865 and extending to February 2023. Each row provides details about a specific incident.

  • September 1865, Cadotte Pass, Montana: Trapper James Lumley reported seeing a craft and its subsequent crash, noting sulfur smells and hieroglyphics.

  • 1896–1897, Multiple Locations, Multiple States: Sightings of airship-like vehicles were reported across the United States during this period, known as the Mystery airship wave.

  • April 17, 1897, Aurora, Texas: Residents claimed an airship crashed, and the deceased alien pilot was buried in the local cemetery.

  • February 24, 1942, Los Angeles, California: The “Battle of Los Angeles” involved an alleged enemy attack and anti-aircraft artillery barrage. Initially thought to be a Japanese attack, it was later attributed to “war nerves” and a possible weather balloon. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox called the incident a “false alarm.”

  • August 1945, Jornada del Muerto, New Mexico: Two boys reported seeing an “avocado-shaped” object crash, containing insect-like alien creatures, shortly after the first atomic bomb detonation.

  • June 21, 1947, Maury Island, Washington: This incident predates the Kenneth Arnold sighting and involves a reported encounter with “men in black” suits.

  • June 24, 1947, Mount Rainier, Washington: Kenneth Arnold reported seeing nine unusual objects flying in formation near Mount Rainier. His description of the objects’ erratic flight and tremendous speed gained widespread media attention.

  • July 1947, Roswell, New Mexico: The Roswell UFO Incident involves the recovery of materials near Roswell, becoming a subject of intense speculation. The military claims it was a crashed research balloon, while ufologists believe it was an alien craft.

  • January 7, 1948, Maysville, Kentucky: The Mantell Incident involved the death of Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a Kentucky Air National Guard pilot, while pursuing a UFO.

  • July 24, 1948, Montgomery, Alabama: The Chiles-Whitted UFO Encounter involves two commercial pilots reporting a near-collision with a torpedo-shaped object.

  • October 1, 1948, Fargo, North Dakota: The Gorman Dogfight involves a US Air Force pilot sighting and pursuing a UFO for 27 minutes.

  • May 11, 1950, McMinnville, Oregon: Paul and Evelyn Trent took the McMinnville UFO photographs on their farm.

  • May 29, 1950, Mount Vernon, Maryland: Captain Willis Sperry and crewmembers on an American Airlines DC-6 reported a “brilliant, diffused, bluish light.”

  • August 15, 1950, Great Falls, Montana: The Mariana UFO incident garnered national media attention during a period of high interest in UFOs and alien invasion.

  • August 25, 1951, Lubbock, Texas: The Lubbock Lights were a v-shaped formation of lights seen over the town.

  • May 24, 1952, Burbank, California: Orfeo Angelucci claimed to encounter flying saucers and their pilots during his drives home from an aircraft plant.

  • July 13, 1952, Washington, D.C.: The 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident involved multiple reports of unidentified flying objects over the city.

  • September 12, 1952, Flatwoods, West Virginia: Six boys and a woman reported seeing a UFO landing and a bizarre-looking creature.

  • November 23, 1953, Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan: Felix Moncla, Jr., a US Air Force pilot, disappeared with 2nd Lt. Robert Wilson while pursuing a UFO over Lake Superior.

  • November 2, 1957, Levelland, Texas: The Levelland UFO case involved multiple witnesses reporting unusual aerial phenomena.

  • September 19, 1961, Lancaster, New Hampshire: Betty and Barney Hill claimed to have been abducted by extraterrestrials, marking the first widely publicized UFO abduction report.

  • April 24, 1964, Socorro, New Mexico: Police officer Lonnie Zamora reported a close encounter with a UFO.

  • September 3, 1965, Exeter, New Hampshire: The Exeter incident involved multiple witnesses, including police officers, observing a large UFO.

  • December 9, 1965, Kecksburg, Pennsylvania: The Kecksburg UFO incident involved a large fireball seen over multiple states and Ontario, Canada, with reports of metal debris.

  • 1969, Leary, Georgia: Jimmy Carter claimed to have seen a UFO and filed a report with the International UFO Bureau.

  • October 11, 1973, Pascagoula, Mississippi: The Pascagoula Abduction involves Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker reporting an alien abduction.

  • January 12, 1975, North Bergen, New Jersey: The Stonehenge incident occurred near the Stonehenge apartment building in North Bergen.

  • November 5, 1975, Snowflake, Arizona: Travis Walton claims to have been abducted by a UFO while working on a logging crew.

  • December 17, 1977, Council Bluffs, Iowa: Local residents reported seeing a reddish fireball and a grass fire where molten metal was recovered.

  • August 27, 1979, Stephen, Minnesota: Deputy Sheriff Val Johnson’s patrol car was struck by a ball of light, causing damage and knocking him unconscious.

  • December 29, 1980, Dayton, Texas: The Cash-Landrum Incident involved a reported UFO sighting and subsequent health issues for the witnesses.

  • November 11, 1987, Gulf Breeze, Florida: The Gulf Breeze UFO incident occurred.

  • March 8, 1994, Multiple Locations, Michigan: Over 100 witnesses reported seeing objects with colored lights across West Michigan.

  • March 13, 1997, Phoenix, Arizona: The Phoenix Lights involved thousands of people witnessing lights of varying descriptions. Former Arizona governor Fife Symington admitted to seeing a delta-shaped craft.

  • January 5, 2000, Highland, Illinois: Five police officers and other witnesses reported a massive, silent, triangular aircraft.

  • August 21, 2004, Chicago, Illinois: A triangular formation of reddish lights was seen by hundreds of witnesses.

  • November 7, 2006, Chicago, Illinois: Airport employees reported a metallic, saucer-shaped craft hovering over O’Hare International Airport.

  • January 5, 2009, Morristown, New Jersey: Five red objects were seen over Morristown. The incident was later revealed to be a hoax by Joe Rudy and Chris Russo.

  • February 19, 2018, Desert, Arizona: Commercial pilots reported seeing an unidentified object, later attributed to a “high-altitude research balloon.”

  • February 21, 2021, Clayton, New Mexico: A pilot reported seeing a long cylindrical object moving rapidly.

  • February 10, 2023, Deadhorse, Alaska: A high-altitude object was shot down over the Beaufort Sea.

  • February 12, 2023, Lake Huron, Michigan: An octagonal object was detected and shot down over Lake Huron.
